In the blocks meta (https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/1427) we have https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/100 listed as what seems to have initially been a task/request for fieldable blocks, but that evolved into the "rabbit hole" feature for content types. ...I'm trying to wrap my head around use cases for fieldable blocks in D8/D9, and if the respective feature we have implemented in Backdrop core is enough to cover those use cases.

[META] Blocks Blocks Blocks · Issue #1427 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
Meta issue to help keep track of all the block related issues and initiatives, including converting the existing custom blocks into fieldable entities and creating a new type of custom text block t...
Add a system of page-less nodes · Issue #100 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
Since we will soon have relegated blocks to being an admin-only text-only layout element that's saved into config, we are going to need a content-based alternative that is a fieldable entity! B...
...in other words, the question is this:
D8+ has fieldable blocks, whereas Backdrop doesn't. Which things can people achieve with fieldable blocks that are not possible in Backdrop?
...I'm aware that we have the "Existing content" block type, and also able to place individual fields as blocks if the context specified for the layout is set to node/%
...what is it that we are missing w/o fieldable blocks in Backdrop?
...you know what? Please hold replies to the above ^^ ...I'll create a forum topic for that.

Which things can people achieve with fieldable blocks that are not possible in Backdrop?

I'm not missing anything. :wink:

It's actually easier to use a content type, hide the path for visitors and include the node(s) in a layout. Easier for users and easier for admins. And if only some parts of a node are needed, a custom layout context will help.

@indigoxela thanks for the very prompt response :+1: ...if you have a forum account, can you please add the above as a response to the forum topic (it will help people reading that in the future, whereas chat messages are lost in time)

So I've been watching https://drupalize.me/videos/introduction-context-and-bean?p=1800 and it mentions that with the Context module in D7 you were able to hide entire regions ...we don't have that ability with layout regions in Backdrop, but we have https://github.com/backdrop/backdrop-issues/issues/1691 which could solve the same use case I think.

Introduction to Context and Bean
As Drupal site-builders and developers we are all very aware that Drupal 7 is not the most useful product out of the box. We constantly add modules and custom code to make Drupal do what we need. There is nothing wrong with this, in fact it is what attracts people to using Drupal in the first place.  The block system that comes with core is what we get after installation as our real only means to laying "stuff" out for our website. People have done things like turning nodes into blocks, or making every block on our a site a view.
[UX] Layout UI: Collapsible block groups. · Issue #1691 · backdrop/backdrop-issues
I've been reading the various issues people have recently opened about problems they are facing while trying to work with translation of various things in order to build multilingual sites and ...

...the video also mentions that besides visibility conditions, there were "actions" that could for example conditionally "move" (render) the block to a different region. Do people use that or find that a potentially useful thing?
